image.altText: A composite image of Peter Genders and Janet with photos of building defects in the background.

items.synopsis: It's the biggest investment most people make, but in the "buyer beware" market, what you see is not always what you get, as these people found out.

title.children: Most of the buildings on Janet's new property are illegal. She says she didn't know

image.altText: Taylor Swift – slim, with straight blonde hair and wearing a legless leotard – sings into a mic during a live performance.

items.synopsis: Much to the disappointment of Swifties in the Sunshine State, Brisbane will miss out on the superstar's Eras tour. A stadium manager explains why.

title.children: Brisbane was 'definitely holding dates' at huge stadium for Taylor Swift, but she's not coming. Here's why

image.altText: A submersible vessel is seen underwater, attached to a larger platform

items.synopsis: More ships are set to join the search for a tourist submersible with five people on board, as more noises are heard in the depths of the North Atlantic.

title.children: Search for missing submersible narrows in on area where noises heard for second day

image.altText: A ship involved in the search for the missing OceanGate submersible in the North Atlantic.

items.synopsis: Authorities say the search for the submersible missing near the Titanic wreck is entering a critical stage, with fears the five occupants will run out of oxygen and develop hypothermia if not found soon. Follow live.

title.children: Search for missing submersible enters crucial stage as oxygen due to run out

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: how  much time would they have left and when would it run out (australia standard time) - Sam. Hi Sam, The Titan left on Sunday with 96 hours of oxygen, which is estimated to run out at roughly 10am GMT, which roughly 7pm AEST tonight. However at 1:00am this morning there was an estimated 20 hours of oxygen remaining.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 96 hours of oxygen due to run out tonight

children.content: how  much time would they have left and when would it run out (australia standard time)
- Sam
Hi Sam,
The Titan left on Sunday with 96 hours of oxygen, which is estimated to run out at roughly 10am GMT, which roughly
7pm AEST tonight.
However at 1:00am this morning there was an estimated 20 hours of oxygen remaining.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: By North America correspondent Barbara Miller As the hours tick by more it's becoming clearer that some industry analysts held grave concerns about OceanGate's operations long before the Titan went missing. Former merchant marine Sal Mercogliano says it appears the company had no real contingency plan. "You dive with a buddy, you have a back-up plan, whether you're a scuba diver or your submersible operator there's always, 'What is the plan B?'" "It doesn't seem like OceanGate had a plan B." Yet Mercogliano emphasises that the company wasn't breaking laws by operating without more checks and balances, because of the fact that the dives were taking place in international waters. "You know, once you get more than 12 miles out, it's kind of the wild, wild West."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Titan operating in 'wild west' without apparent plan B

children.content: By North America correspondent Barbara Miller
As the hours tick by more it's becoming clearer that some industry analysts held grave concerns about OceanGate's operations long before the Titan went missing.
Former merchant marine
Sal Mercogliano
says it appears the company had no real contingency plan.
"You dive with a buddy, you have a back-up plan, whether you're a scuba diver or your submersible operator there's always, 'What is the plan B?'"
"It doesn't seem like OceanGate had a plan B."
Yet Mercogliano emphasises that the company wasn't breaking laws by operating without more checks and balances, because of the fact that the dives were taking place in international waters.
"You know, once you get more than 12 miles out, it's kind of the wild, wild West."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The short answer is: not very much, especially with five occupants on board. The submersible is about 6.7 metres in length, with a width of just 2.5 metres inside. The submersible is also shaped like a cylinder, so its passengers would be sitting against a curved wall. It can dive to a depth of 4,000 metres and and weighs 9.5 tonnes. Critically, it has 96 hours of oxygen for five people, but the search has been going for days.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How much room is in the submersible?

children.content: The short answer is: not very much, especially with five occupants on board.
The submersible is about 6.7 metres in length, with a width of just 2.5 metres inside.

props.alt: A photo of the submersible with measurements.

children.content: (Associated Press/ABC News)
The submersible is also shaped like a cylinder, so its passengers would be sitting against a curved wall.
It can dive to a depth of 4,000 metres and and weighs 9.5 tonnes.
Critically, it has 96 hours of oxygen for five people, but the search has been going for days.

image.altText: An alarmed woman wearing a bikini on a beach stands up as a dingo looks at her bottom.

items.synopsis: A young boy is the latest to fall prey to a dingo on K'gari, where thousands of tourists are expected to flock for the mid-year break. Authorities say the animals are exhibiting a concerning "level of dominance".

title.children: Boy, 10, dragged under water by dingo after French tourist, others attacked on K'gari (Fraser Island)

image.altText: Wayne Fosser

items.synopsis: The end of financial year is just over a week away, meaning it's a good time to start getting return-ready. There is also help available if you're a vulnerable taxpayer and need free advice.

title.children: Wayne avoided his tax return for more than a decade, until he found some welcome free advice

image.altText: A split image of a grassy park with a bench and house in the background, and an older woman with white hair.

items.synopsis: Residents on Russell Island in south-east Queensland have been urging the local council to redevelop a block of land into a park with a playground, an outdoor gym, and more vegetation.

image.altText: A woman sits on a couch and holds a phone to her ear.

image.altText: Firemen use a water canon as they fight a blaze in Paris.

image.altText: A man in a helmet smiles as blood dribbles from his lip.

image.altText: A crowd member holds their smartphone with two hands, recording. The stage is seen through the screen.

items.synopsis: Attendees of the This Never Happened festival will be issued with stickers to cover the lenses of their smartphones preventing them from recording the gig or taking photos, aimed at turning back the clock on the audience experience.

title.children: These artists are banning phones from their shows. They say it's better

image.altText: A red Ferrari car with its door open

items.synopsis: Police seize luxury cars worth approximately $2.7 million after investigating what they allege is a cryptocurrency scam that defrauded two companies.

title.children: $600k Ferrari seized by police as alleged $5.5m Sydney cryptocurrency scam busted

image.altText: Side by side photos of Anthony Albanese and Adam Bandt, both in dark suits, ties and spectacles

items.synopsis: The delicate relationship between Labor and the Greens often swings from confrontation to cooperation. But this week, during the stand-off over the government's housing bill, something snapped, writes David Speers.

title.children: Labor and the Greens aren't strangers to conflict. But in this week's housing stand-off, something snapped

image.altText: The side of a black Amazon Prime delivery vehicle, with a blue arrrow and the word "Prime" in white, shot from a low angle

items.synopsis: The US Federal Trade Commission says Amazon uses deceptive "dark patterns" to enrol customers in its paid-for premium service.

title.children: Amazon accused of duping millions of customers over Prime sign-ups

image.altText: A blonde woman holds a handful of avocados up to the camera and smiles.

items.synopsis: Far North Queenslanders have rallied in support of an avocado producer facing the prospect of having to dump three tonnes of fruit. The avocado oversupply is expected to cause more pain for growers in the years to come.

image.altText: Andrew Tate is pictured, two bald men with sunglasses walk besides him while one raises his arm seemingly to protect Tate.

items.synopsis: Andrew Tate, a social media personality known for expressing misogynistic views online, has appeared in a court in Romania, where prosecutors have charged him with rape, human trafficking and forming a criminal gang to exploit women.

title.children: Andrew Tate appears in Romanian court on rape, human trafficking charges

image.altText: Post-dip exhilaration for nude swim participants in red caps.

items.synopsis: With the air temperature dipping to just 3 degrees Celsius, it was a bracing start for the 2,000 people who ditched their gear and pitched into the River Derwent for the annual Dark Mofo nude swim.

title.children: 'So cold it burned': Rude shock for nude swimmers as Hobart puts on chilly start

image.altText: A close up of Yevgeny Prigozhin and Vladimir Putin.

items.synopsis: As Russia moves to take control of Wagner with its push for recruits to sign contracts before July 1, Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the mercenary group, has vowed a boycott. Now everyone is waiting to see if he will ultimately bend to the Russian leader's will — and what happens if he refuses.

title.children: Vladimir Putin versus Yevgeny Prigozhin: Why the Russian dictator's only friend might now be his worst nightmare

image.altText: Sunrise aerial shot of Lawn Hill Gorge in Boodjamulla National Park. Lots of pinks and purples on the skyline.

items.synopsis: Indigenous cultural sites have been damaged at Boodjamulla National Park (Lawn Hill) with the closure of the iconic travel hotspot putting a dent in an already-suffering tourism industry in outback Queensland.

title.children: Outback national park made famous by Chris Hemsworth ad closes indefinitely

image.altText: A man looks bemused during an Origin match

items.synopsis: A New South Wales era ended in frustrating and dire fashion at Lang Park as the Blues once again failed to get out of their own way.

title.children: How cruel twists of fate and self-inflicted wounds ended an era for New South Wales

image.altText: a wide shot of a housing estate showing multiple properties

items.synopsis: New research suggests Australia's housing market will continue to recover from the 2022 downturn and reach new high prices by mid-next year, while more interest rate rises are likely on the way in the US and England. Follow live.

title.children: House prices to reach new record in coming financial year, rate hikes likely in US and UK, ASX opens lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Major gas customers say the gas price cap introduced by the federal government is failing to keep prices low, and is instead acting as a floor. Last year the federal government imposed price caps on the wholesale coal and gas markets to deliver cost certainty for gas users. But gas producers say that objective has failed, because gas suppliers have effectively gone on strike over the market intervention. It's not just gas producers that are feeling the effects of the price cap — it's flowing through to gas users and consumers, through higher energy bills, and some are concerned it's contributing to inflation, and driving up interest rates as a result. So what can be done? You can read the full story from my colleague Rhiana Whitson below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The gas cap was meant to help with power prices, but some say it's adding to inflation

featuredLink.title: Gas price cap 'overwhelmed by suppliers' strike'. So where to now for the government to limit energy price rises?

children.content: Major gas customers say the gas price cap introduced by the federal government is failing to keep prices low, and is instead acting as a floor.
Last year the federal government imposed price caps on the wholesale coal and gas markets to deliver cost certainty for gas users.
But gas producers say that objective has failed, because gas suppliers have effectively gone on strike over the market intervention.

It's not just gas producers that are feeling the effects of the price cap — it's flowing through to gas users and consumers, through higher energy bills, and some are concerned it's contributing to inflation, and driving up interest rates as a result.
So what can be done? You can read the full story from my colleague Rhiana Whitson below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As expected, the Australian sharemarket has opened lower, down 0.7% as of 10:30am AEST. The falls are being felt across most of the sectors, with only utilities, energy and consumer non-cyclicals only up a fraction. So far the academic services sector is down the most, shedding 1.4%, while basic materials and financials are down 0.5% each. The top five performers so far: Regis Resources +1.2% IGO Ltd +0.9% Elders +0.6% Monadelphous Group +0.5% News Crop +0.5% The five worst performers so far: Gold Road Resources -5.9% Megaport -2.8% Hub24 -2.2% Carsales.com -2.1% Northern Star Resources -2.1%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower as Gold Road, Carsales shares tumble

children.content: As expected, the Australian sharemarket has opened lower, down 0.7% as of 10:30am AEST.
The falls are being felt across most of the sectors, with only utilities, energy and consumer non-cyclicals only up a fraction.
So far the academic services sector is down the most, shedding 1.4%, while basic materials and financials are down 0.5% each.
The top five performers so far:
Regis Resources +1.2%
IGO Ltd +0.9%
Elders +0.6%
Monadelphous Group +0.5%
News Crop +0.5%
The five worst performers so far:

Megaport -2.8%
Carsales.com -2.1%
Northern Star Resources -2.1%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Late yesterday a scathing interim parliamentary report into the PwC tax leak scandal was released, finding that the consulting firm engaged in a "calculated breach of trust", but stopped short of naming all staff involved in the leaks. The report found PwC engaged in a "deliberate strategy over many years" to cover up the breach, and has recommended PwC publicly disclose further details about those involved in the leaking of confidential tax documents. Speaking on RN Breakfast this morning, Treasurer Jim Chalmers said he wants to see more transparency and scrutiny of PwC. "Certainly we want to see an element of transparency here, and the committee is capable of doing their work without my guidance necessarily," he said. "We need to know more information certainly, we need to know much more about what's happened here as part of our efforts to make sure it doesn't happen again. "There's a committee process doing a great job, there's the AFP referral, there's all of our other efforts, as well. "We will get to the bottom of this, and we will make sure that it doesn't happen again. "It is deeply, deeply disappointing, completely unacceptable, and the government and the parliament more broadly is acting decisively to deal with it."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: More scrutiny of PwC needed, Chalmers says

children.content: Late yesterday a scathing interim parliamentary report into the PwC tax leak scandal was released, finding that the consulting firm engaged in a "calculated breach of trust", but stopped short of naming all staff involved in the leaks.

The report found PwC engaged in a "deliberate strategy over many years" to cover up the breach, and has recommended PwC publicly disclose further details about those involved in the leaking of confidential tax documents.
Speaking on RN Breakfast this morning, Treasurer Jim Chalmers said he wants to see more transparency and scrutiny of PwC.
"Certainly we want to see an element of transparency here, and the committee is capable of doing their work without my guidance necessarily," he said.
"We need to know more information certainly, we need to know much more about what's happened here as part of our efforts to make sure it doesn't happen again.
"There's a committee process doing a great job, there's the AFP referral, there's all of our other efforts, as well.
"We will get to the bottom of this, and we will make sure that it doesn't happen again.
"It is deeply, deeply disappointing, completely unacceptable, and the government and the parliament more broadly is acting decisively to deal with it."

image.altText: A woman with braided hair looks at a dog.

image.altText: The Twitter app icon is seen on an iPhone with a green background.
